title: Jeremy Corbyn backs second referendum after ‘even worse deal than Theresa May’s’
text:
Corbyn wants a second EU referendum (Picture: AP)

Jeremy Corbyn announced that Labour will officially back a second referendum as he dismissed Boris Johnson’s new Brexit deal with the EU.

The Labour leader called the deal ‘even worse than Theresa May’s’ which was rejected three times in the House of Commons.

He said: ‘These proposals risk triggering a race to the bottom on rights and protections: putting food safety at risk, cutting environmental standards and workers’ rights, and opening up our NHS to a takeover by US private corporations.

‘This sell-out deal won’t bring the country together and should be rejected.

‘The best way to get Brexit sorted is to give the people the final say in a public vote.’

The prime minister announced the Brexit deal on Twitter, saying: ‘We’ve got a great new deal that takes back control – now Parliament should get Brexit done on Saturday so we can move on to other priorities like the cost of living, the NHS, violent crime and our environment.’

Mr Johnson in Downing Street after hashing out a deal (Picture: PA)

The revelation came after days of intense negotiations with EU leaders ahead of a crucial two-day summit in Brussels.

The next hurdle comes on Saturday, when Mr Johnson faces an uphill battle to get MPs in Parliament to sign off on the deal.

The Commons will sit for its first weekend session for 37 years to hash out the next steps on Brexit.

However, the DUP insisted it still could not yet back the Government’s Brexit plans.

The stance of the DUP is important because the party wields influence over some Tory Brexiteers.

European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker tweeted: ‘Where there is a will, there is a #deal – we have one!

‘It’s a fair and balanced agreement for the EU and the UK and it is testament to our commitment to find solutions. I recommend that #EUCO endorses this deal.’

Arlene Foster, DUP leader, has said her party does not back Boris’ deal with the EU (Picture: LNP)

A Downing Street spokeswoman said the deal agreed between the UK and EU does get rid of the Irish backstop.

She said it is the ‘best deal for the UK’ and that the prime minister ‘thinks MPs should get behind it’.

The spokeswoman added: ‘It protects the Union, removes the backstop, deals with unique circumstances on the island of Ireland and allows the UK to leave the EU in an orderly way on 31 October.’
